text: 1. This then becomes perfect as a thousand of B ri hatî verses. Its consonants 1 form its body, its voice 2 (vowels) the Soul 3 , its sibilants 4 the air of the breath.

text: 2. He who knew this became Vasish th a, he took this name from thence 5 .

text: 3. Indra verily declared this to Vi s vâmitra, and Indra verily declared this to Bharadvâga. Therefore Indra is invoked by him as a friend 6 .

upanishad: The Upanishads, Part 1 (SBE01): Aitareya-Âranyaka: ... | Sacred Texts Archive

text: 4. This becomes perfect as a thousand of B ri hatî verses 7 , and of that hymn perfect with a thousand Brihad verses, there are 36,000 syllables 8 . So many are also the thousands of days of a hundred years (36,000). With the consonants they fill the nights, with the vowels the days.

upanishad: The Upanishads, Part 1 (SBE01): Aitareya-Âranyaka: ... | Sacred Texts Archive
translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 5. This becomes perfect as a thousand of B ri hatî verses. He who knows this, after this thousand of B ri hatîs thus accomplished, becomes full of knowledge, full of the gods, full of Brahman, full of the immortal, and then goes also to the gods.

upanishad: The Upanishads, Part 1 (SBE01): Aitareya-Âranyaka: ... | Sacred Texts Archive
translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 6. What I am (the worshipper), that is he (sun); what he is, that am I.
